document.masterDocTitle: Redescriptions and descriptions of new species of Austrostrongylus Chandler, 1924 (Nematoda: Trichostrongylina), from Australian marsupials with a comparative study of features of the synlophe

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Redescriptions and descriptions of new species of Austrostrongylus Chandler, 1924 (Nematoda: Trichostrongylina), from Australian marsupials with a comparative study of features of the synlophe

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Departement de Systématique et Evolution, Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle, UMR 7138 associée au CNRS CP 52 61 rue Buffon, 75231 Paris, France
Department of Veterinary Science, University of Melbourne, Veterinary Clinical Centre, Werribee, Victoria 3030, Australia.

bibRefCitation.author: Mawson, P. M.
bibRefCitation.refString: Mawson, P. M. (1973) Amidostomatinae (Nematoda: Trichostrongyloidea) from Australian marsupials and monotremes. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Australia, 97, 257 - 279.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type host:
Macropus rufogriseus (Desmarest)
.

Other hosts:
M. fuliginosus (Desmarest)
,
M. giganteus Shaw
,
Wallabia bicolor (Desmarest)
.
Site in host: small intestine.

From
Macropus fuliginosus
: Victoria : 3 ♂♂ , Brimpaen (
SAM 45898
)
.
Synlophe: In male, oesophageal and median third of body studied in 1 male 6.0 mm long, distal third in 1 male 6.1 mm long. Entire body studied in 1 female 5.6 mm long.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 4 .
Austrostrongylus chandleri Mawson, 1973
from
Macropus rufogriseus
. A . Anterior end, ♂, left lateral view; B . Cephalic extremity, ♂, right lateral view; C. Cephalic extremity, ♂, apical view; D . Spicule tips, ventro-lateral view. E . Spicules. F . Genital cone, apical view; G . Genital cone, left lateral view; H . Gubernaculum, ventral view; I . Gubernaculum, lateral view; J . Female tail, right lateral view; K . Bursa, left lateral view showing inflated dorsal lobe; L . Vulva and ovejector, right lateral view; M . Bursa, ventral view. Scale-bars: Figs. A, E, J–M, 0.1 mm; Figs. B–D, F–I, 0.01 mm.

FIGURE 5 .
Austrostrongylus chandleri Mawson, 1973
from
Macropus rufogriseus .
Drawn from males, vouchers (SAM 45718). A–G : male 6.0 mm long, H–N : male 6.1 mm long. A–E : oesophageal region. A . 40 µm posterior to cephalic vesicle; B . 160 µm posterior to cephalic vesicle; C . 200 µm posterior to cephalic vesicle; D . Level of excretory pore; E . Level of oesophago-intestinal junction; F , G : median third of body: F . Mid-body (46.7 % of body length); G . End of second third. Distal quarter of body: H–N . H. 1.0 mm anterior to bursa (1.2 mm from caudal extremity); I . 820 µm anterior to bursa; J . at 760 µm anterior to caudal bursa. K . 710 µm anterior to bursa. L . 650 µm anterior to bursa. M . 600 µm anterior to bursa. N . Just anterior to bursa. Arrows indicate disappearance of ridges. Drawings oriented as in Fig. 5F. Abbreviations: v: ventral; r: right lateral; RF: right float; LF: left float. Scale-bar: 50 µm.

FIGURE 6 .
Austrostrongylus chandleri Mawson, 1973
from
Macropus rufogriseus .
Drawings of female, voucher (SAM 45718), 5.6 mm long. A–F : oesophageal region. A . 40 µm posterior to cephalic vesicle; B . 90 µm posterior to cephalic vesicle; C . 190 µm posterior to cephalic vesicle; D . 240 µm posterior to cephalic vesicle. E . Level of excretory pore; F . 50 µm posterior to oesophago-intestinal junction; G , H : median third of body. G . Mid-body (50 % of body length); H . 450 µm posterior to midbody; I–N : distal third of body. I . 1.4 mm anterior to vulva (2.2 mm anterior to caudal extremity); J . 1.3 mm anterior to vulva; K . 1.2 mm anterior to vulva; L . 900 µm anterior to vulva; M . 850 µm anterior to vulva; N . 600 µm anterior to vulva. Arrows indicate disappearance of ridges. Drawings oriented as in Fig. 6G. Abbreviations: v: ventral; r: right lateral; RF: right float; LF: left float. Scale-bar: 50 µm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Remarks. The general features of this species were well described by Mawson (1973) and it is readily recognisable by its slender yellow spicules and enlarged spicule tips.

The current collections substantially expand the known geographical range of the parasite to Victoria , New South Wales , South Australia and Tasmania , as well as adding
M. giganteus
as a new, if incidental, host. An additional collection from
W. bicolor
from Nowra, NSW confirms Mawson's observation (1973) that although primarily a parasite of
M. rufogriseus
,
A. chandleri
can also infect
W. bicolor
where the two host species co-occur.
Aussavy et al. (2011)
reported a prevalence of 46% of
A. chandleri
in
M. rufogriseus
in Victoria , with 10–11% prevalence in sympatric
M. fuliginosus
and
M. giganteus
. However, they did not find the species in the
10
W.
bicolor they examined.
